'''Citizen science''' ('''CS'''; also known as '''community science''', '''crowd science''', '''crowd-sourced science''', '''civic science''', '''volunteer monitoring''', or '''networked science''') is [[scientific research]] conducted, in whole or in part, by [[amateur]] (or nonprofessional) [[scientist]]s.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Gura, Trisha|title=Citizen science: amateur experts|journal=Nature|volume=496|issue=7444|year=2013|pages=259–261|doi=10.1038/nj7444-259a}}</ref> Citizen science is sometimes described as "[[public participation]] in scientific research," [[participatory monitoring]], and [[participatory action research]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Hand |first1 = E. |title = Citizen science: People power |doi = 10.1038/466685a |journal = Nature |volume = 466 |issue = 7307 |pages = 685–687 |year = 2010 |pmid = 20686547|pmc =}}</ref> [[File:Scanning the cliffs near Logan Pass for mountain goats (Citizen Science) (4427399123).jpg|thumb|right|Scanning the cliffs near [[Logan Pass]] for mountain goats as part of the [[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park]] Citizen Science Program]]
== Definition ==
The term CS has multiple origins, as well as differing concepts.<ref name="Re&Po">{{cite web|url=https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0963662513497324|title=Citizen science as seen by scientists: Methodological, epistemological and ethical dimensions|author1=H. Riesch|first=|author2=C. Potter|date=2014|website=|pages=107–120|doi=10.1177/0963662513497324|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=|journal=Public Understanding of Science|volume=23|issue=1}}</ref> It was first defined independently in the mid-1990s by Rick Bonney in the United States and Alan Irwin in the United Kingdom.<ref name=Re&Po/><ref name=A.I.>{{cite book|author=Alan Irwin|title=Citizen Science: A Study of People, Expertise and Sustainable Development|publisher=Routledge|date=1995|pages=}}</ref><ref name=R.Bonney>{{cite journal|author1=R. Bonney|author2=H. Ballard|author3=R. Jordan|author4=E. McCallie|author5=T. Phillips|author6=J. Shirk|author7=C. C. Wilderman|title=Bonney et al. 2009 CAISE Report on Public Participation in Scientific Research. A CAISE Inquiry Group Report|journal=Washington, D.C.: Center for Advancement of Informal Science Education (CAISE)|date=2009}}</ref> Alan Irwin, a British sociologist, defines CS as "developing concepts of scientific citizenship which foregrounds the necessity of opening up science and science policy processes to the public".<ref name=Re&Po/> Irwin sought to reclaim two dimensions of the relationship between citizens and science: 1) that science should be responsive to citizens' concerns and needs; and 2) that citizens themselves could produce reliable scientific knowledge.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=The Rightful Place of Science: Citizen Science|last=Cavalier|first=Darlene|last2=Kennedy|first2=Eric|publisher=Consortium for Science, Policy & Outcomes|year=2016|isbn=9780692694831|location=Tempe, AZ|page=54|quote=|via=}}</ref> The American ornithologist Rick Bonney, unaware of Irwin's work, defined CS as projects in which nonscientists, such as amateur birdwatchers, voluntarily contributed scientific data. This describes a more limited role for citizens in scientific research than Irwin's conception of the term.<ref name=":2" />
The terms ''citizen science'' and ''citizen scientists'' entered the [[Oxford English Dictionary]] (''OED'') in June 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=New words list June 2014|url=http://public.oed.com/the-oed-today/recent-updates-to-the-oed/previous%20updates/june-2014-update/new-words-list-june-2014|publisher=Oxford English Dictionary|accessdate=3 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509083230/http://public.oed.com/the-oed-today/recent-updates-to-the-oed/previous%20updates/june-2014-update/new-words-list-june-2014|archivedate=9 May 2016|df=}}</ref><ref name=Zoo_OED>{{cite web|title='Citizen science' added to Oxford English Dictionary|url=https://daily.zooniverse.org/2014/09/16/citizen-science-in-dictionary|publisher=The Daily Zooniverse|date=16 September 2014|accessdate=3 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160616165001/https://daily.zooniverse.org/2014/09/16/citizen-science-in-dictionary/|archivedate=16 June 2016|df=}}</ref> "Citizen science" is defined as "scientific work undertaken by members of the general public, often in collaboration with or under the direction of professional scientists and scientific institutions".<ref name=Zoo_OED/> "Citizen scientist" is defined as: (a) "a scientist whose work is characterized by a sense of responsibility to serve the best interests of the wider community (now rare)"; or (b) "a member of the general public who engages in scientific work, often in collaboration with or under the direction of professional scientists and scientific institutions; an amateur scientist".<ref name=Zoo_OED/> The first use of the term "citizen scientist" can be found in the magazine ''[[New Scientist]]'' in an article about [[ufology]] from October 1979.<ref name=Oberg>{{cite magazine|title=The Failure of the 'Science' of Ufology|author=James Oberg|journal=New Scientist|date=11 October 1979|volume=84|issue=1176|pages=102–105}}</ref>
Muki Haklay cites, from a policy report for the [[Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars|Wilson Center]] entitled "Citizen Science and Policy: A European Perspective", an alternate first use of the term "citizen science" by R. Kerson in the magazine ''[[MIT Technology Review]]'' from January 1989.<ref name=1stUse>{{cite web|author=Muki Haklay|title=Citizen Science and Policy: A European Perspective|url=https://www.wilsoncenter.org/sites/default/files/Citizen_Science_Policy_European_Perspective_Haklay.pdf|publisher=Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars|page=11|date=2015|accessdate=3 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018170921/https://www.wilsoncenter.org/sites/default/files/Citizen_Science_Policy_European_Perspective_Haklay.pdf|archivedate=18 October 2016|df=}}</ref><ref name=Kerson>{{cite magazine|author=R. Kerson|title=Lab for the Environment|journal=MIT Technology Review|date=1989|volume=92|issue=1|pages=11–12}}</ref> Quoting from the Wilson Center report: "The new form of engagement in science received the name 'citizen science'. The first recorded example of the use of the term is from 1989, describing how 225 volunteers across the US collected rain samples to assist the [[National Audubon Society|Audubon Society]] in an acid-rain awareness raising campaign."<ref name=1stUse/><ref name=Kerson/>
A ''"Green Paper on Citizen Science"'' was published in 2013 by the [[European Commission]]'s Digital Science Unit and Socientize.eu, which included a definition for CS, referring to "the general public engagement in scientific research activities when citizens actively contribute to science either with their intellectual effort or surrounding knowledge or with their tools and resources. Participants provide experimental data and facilities for researchers, raise new questions and co-create a new scientific culture."<ref name=GP_CS_EU>{{cite web|title=Green paper on Citizen Science for Europe: Towards a society of empowered citizens and enhanced research|url=https://ec.europa.eu/digital-single-market/en/news/green-paper-citizen-science-europe-towards-society-empowered-citizens-and-enhanced-research|publisher=European Commission|date=21 January 2014|accessdate=18 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161017015723/https://ec.europa.eu/digital-single-market/en/news/green-paper-citizen-science-europe-towards-society-empowered-citizens-and-enhanced-research|archivedate=17 October 2016|df=}}</ref><ref name=EU_GrPa>{{cite web|title=Green paper on Citizen Science|url=http://ec.europa.eu/newsroom/dae/document.cfm?doc_id=4122|publisher=Socientize.eu|page=6|date=2013|accessdate=18 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151226063915/http://ec.europa.eu/newsroom/dae/document.cfm?doc_id=4122|archivedate=26 December 2015|df=}}</ref>
Citizen science may be performed by individuals, teams, or networks of volunteers. Citizen scientists often partner with professional scientists to achieve common goals. Large volunteer networks often allow scientists to accomplish tasks that would be too expensive or time consuming to accomplish through other means.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Silvertown|first=Jonathan|title=A new dawn for citizen science|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tree.2009.03.017|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|volume=24|issue=9|pages=467–471|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2009.03.017|year=2009}}</ref>
Many citizen-science projects serve education and outreach goals.<ref>{{Cite book |last1 = Osborn |first1 = D. A. |doi = 10.1061/40761(175)57 |chapter = Monitoring Rocky Intertidal Shorelines: A Role for the Public in Resource Management |title = California and the World Ocean 02 |volume = 175 |page = 57 |year = 2002 |isbn = 0-7844-0761-4 |pmid = |pmc =}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Brossard |first1 = D. |last2 = Lewenstein |first2 = B. |last3 = Bonney |first3 = R. |doi = 10.1080/09500690500069483 |title = Scientific knowledge and attitude change: The impact of a citizen science project |journal = International Journal of Science Education |volume = 27 |issue = 9 |pages = 1099–1121 |year = 2005 |pmid = |pmc = |bibcode = 2005IJSEd..27.1099B}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Bauer |first1 = M. W. |last2 = Petkova |first2 = K. |last3 = Boyadjieva |first3 = P. |title = Public Knowledge of and Attitudes to Science: Alternative Measures That May End the "Science War" |doi = 10.1177/016224390002500102 |journal = Science, Technology & Human Values |volume = 25 |pages = 30–51 |year = 2000 |pmid = |pmc =}}</ref> These projects may be designed for a formal classroom environment or an informal education environment such as museums.
Citizen science has evolved over the past four decades. Recent projects place more emphasis on scientifically sound practices and measurable goals for public education.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Bonney |first1 = R. |last2 = Cooper |first2 = C. B. |last3 = Dickinson |first3 = J. |last4 = Kelling |first4 = S. |last5 = Phillips |first5 = T. |last6 = Rosenberg |first6 = K. V. |last7 = Shirk |first7 = J. |doi = 10.1525/bio.2009.59.11.9 |title = Citizen Science: A Developing Tool for Expanding Science Knowledge and Scientific Literacy |journal = BioScience |volume = 59 |issue = 11 |pages = 977–984 |year = 2009 |pmid = |pmc =}}</ref> Modern citizen science differs from its historical forms primarily in the access for, and subsequent scale of, public participation; technology is credited as one of the main drivers of the recent explosion of citizen science activity.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Silvertown |first1 = J. |title = A new dawn for citizen science |doi = 10.1016/j.tree.2009.03.017 |journal = Trends in Ecology & Evolution |volume = 24 |issue = 9 |pages = 467–471|year = 2009 |pmid = |pmc =}}</ref>
In March 2015, the [[Office of Science and Technology Policy]] published a factsheet entitled "Empowering Students and Others through Citizen Science and Crowdsourcing".<ref name=OSTP_2015>{{cite web|title=Fact Sheet: Empowering Students and Others through Citizen Science and Crowdsourcing|author=OSTP|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/microsites/ostp/citizen_science_backgrounder_march-23.pdf|publisher=The White House|date=23 March 2015|accessdate=24 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160322013634/https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/microsites/ostp/citizen_science_backgrounder_march-23.pdf|archivedate=22 March 2016|df=}}</ref> Quoting: "Citizen science and crowdsourcing projects are powerful tools for providing students with skills needed to excel in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Volunteers in citizen science, for example, gain hands-on experience doing real science, and in many cases take that learning outside of the traditional classroom setting".<ref name=OSTP_2015/>
[[File:Cascades Butterfly Project Team (8273990532).jpg|thumb|right|Members of the [[Cascade Range|Cascades]] Butterfly Citizen Science Team pictured on Sauk mountain]] In May 2016, a new [[open-access journal]] was started by the Citizen Science Association along with [[Ubiquity Press]] called ''Citizen Science: Theory and Practice'' (CS:T&P).<ref name=CS:T&P_Web>{{cite web|title=Citizen Science: Theory and Practice|url=http://theoryandpractice.citizenscienceassociation.org|publisher=The Citizen Science Association and Ubiquity Press|date=20 May 2016|accessdate=22 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160524120333/http://theoryandpractice.citizenscienceassociation.org/|archivedate=24 May 2016|df=}}</ref><ref name=CS_T&P>{{cite journal|author1=R. Bonney|author2=C. Cooper|author3=H. Ballard|title=The Theory and Practice of Citizen Science: Launching a New Journal|date=20 May 2016|journal=Citizen Science: Theory and Practice|volume=1|issue=1|page=1|doi=10.5334/cstp.65}}</ref> Quoting from the editorial article titled "The Theory and Practice of Citizen Science: Launching a New Journal", "CS:T&P provides the space to enhance the quality and impact of citizen science efforts by deeply exploring the citizen science concept in all its forms and across disciplines. By examining, critiquing, and sharing findings across a variety of citizen science endeavors, we can dig into the underpinnings and assumptions of citizen science and critically analyze its practice and outcomes."<ref name=CS_T&P/>
===Alternative definitions===
Other definitions for citizen science have also been proposed. For example, Bruce Lewenstein of [[Cornell University]]'s [[Communication studies|Communication]] and [[Science and technology studies|S&TS]] departments describes 3 possible definitions:<ref name=Lewenstein_2004>{{cite web|title=What does citizen science accomplish?|author=B. Lewenstein|url=http://ecommons.library.cornell.edu/handle/1813/37362|publisher=Cornell University|date=8 June 2004|accessdate=16 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141009065556/http://ecommons.library.cornell.edu/handle/1813/37362|archivedate=9 October 2014|df=}}</ref> * The participation of nonscientists in the process of gathering data according to specific scientific protocols and in the process of using and interpreting that data.<ref name=Lewenstein_2004/> * The engagement of nonscientists in true decision-making about policy issues that have technical or scientific components.<ref name=Lewenstein_2004/> * The engagement of research scientists in the democratic and policy process.<ref name=Lewenstein_2004/>
Scientists and scholars who have used other definitions include [[Frank N. von Hippel]], [[Stephen Schneider]], [[Neal Francis Lane|Neal Lane]] and [[Jon Beckwith]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Von Hippel, Frank |title=Citizen scientist |publisher=[[American Institute of Physics]] |location=New York |year=1991 |pages= |isbn=0-88318-709-4 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author=Beckwith, Jonathan R. |authorlink=Jon Beckwith|title=Making genes, making waves: a social activist in science |publisher=Harvard University Press |location=Cambridge |year=2002 |pages= |isbn=0-674-00928-2 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref><ref>Neal Lane, "Remarks" at Panel Discussion on Future of Federal Funding for Science and Engineering, [[Rutgers University]], April 8, 1996. [https://www.nsf.gov/news/speeches/lane/slrtgrs.htm Steve Schneider remarks at AAAS meeting, February 1997] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929095756/https://www.nsf.gov/news/speeches/lane/slrtgrs.htm |date=2007-09-29 }}; see here {{cite web |url=http://news-service.stanford.edu/pr/97/970210schneider.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-08-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070609092054/http://news-service.stanford.edu/pr/97/970210schneider.html |archivedate=2007-06-09 |df= }}.</ref> Other alternative terminologies proposed are "civic science" and "civic scientist".<ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Clark |first1 = F. |last2 = Illman |first2 = D. L. |doi = 10.1177/1075547001023001002 |title = Dimensions of Civic Science: Introductory Essay |journal = Science Communication |volume = 23 |pages = 5–27 |year = 2001 |pmid = |pmc =}}</ref>
Further, Muki Haklay offers an overview of the typologies of the level of citizen participation in citizen science, which range from "crowdsourcing" (level 1), where the citizen acts as a sensor, to "distributed intelligence" (level 2), where the citizen acts as a basic interpreter, to "participatory science", where citizens contribute to problem definition and data collection (level 3), to "extreme citizen science", which involves collaboration between the citizen and scientists in problem definition, collection and data analysis.<ref>Haklay, Muki (2012) in Citizen Science and Volunteered Geographic Information: Overview and Typology of Participation. Crowdsourcing Geographic Knowledge. 2013, pp. 105–122.</ref>
A 2014 [[Mashable]] article defines a citizen scientist as: "Anybody who voluntarily contributes his or her time and resources toward scientific research in partnership with professional scientists."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2014/05/26/citizen-science/|title=What Is Citizen Science, and How Can You Get Involved?|author=Eric Larson|date=26 May 2014|work=Mashable|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171110231048/http://mashable.com/2014/05/26/citizen-science/|archivedate=10 November 2017|df=}}</ref>
In 2016 the Australian Citizen Science Association released their definition which states "Citizen science involves public participation and collaboration in scientific research with the aim to increase scientific knowledge."<ref name=ACSA_1>{{cite web| title=What is Citizen Science?| url=https://citizenscience.org.au/who-we-are| publisher=Australian Citizen Science Association| access-date=10 July 2018}}</ref><ref name=ACSA_2>{{cite web| title=Discover Another Side of Scientific Research| url=https://citizenscience.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/Australian-Citizen-Science-Association-brochure.pdf| publisher=Australian Citizen Science Association| access-date=10 July 2018}}</ref>
In 2016, the book "Analyzing the Role of Citizen Science in Modern Research" defined citizen science as "work undertaken by civic educators together with citizen communities to advance science, foster a broad scientific mentality, and/or encourage democratic engagement, which allows society to deal rationally with complex modern problems".<ref>{{cite web| title=Analyzing the role of citizen science in modern research|author=Ceccaroni, L., & Piera, J. (Eds.)|date=2016| url=https://www.igi-global.com/book/analyzing-role-citizen-science-modern/154745| publisher=IGI Global| access-date=27 September 2018}}</ref>
===Related fields===
In a [[Smart City]] era, Citizen Science relays on various web-based tools (eg.[[Web mapping|WebGIS)]] and becomes Cyber Citizen Science.<ref name=WebGIS_1>{{cite journal| title=Citizen science and WebGIS for outdoor advertisement visual pollution assessment| author1=S. Chmielewski| author2=M. Samulowska| author3=M. Lupa| author4=B. Zagajewski| journal=Computers Environment and Urban Systems| date=September 2017| volume=67| pages=97–109| doi=10.1016/j.compenvurbsys.2017.09.001}}</ref> Some projects, such as [[SETI@home]], use the Internet to take advantage of [[distributed computing]]. These projects are generally passive. Computation tasks are performed by volunteers' computers and require little involvement beyond initial setup. There is disagreement as to whether these projects should be classified as citizen science.
The astrophysicist and [[Galaxy Zoo]] co-founder [[Kevin Schawinski]] stated: "We prefer to call this [Galaxy Zoo] citizen science because it's a better description of what you're doing; you're a regular citizen but you're doing science. Crowd sourcing sounds a bit like, well, you're just a member of the crowd and you're not; you're our collaborator. You're pro-actively involved in the process of science by participating."<ref name=AnthonyWilliams>{{cite web|title=Crowdsourcing versus citizen science|author=A. Williams|url=http://anthonydwilliams.com/2009/02/09/crowdsourcing-versus-citizen-science|publisher=Anthony D. Williams|date=9 February 2009|accessdate=15 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20140917045411/http://anthonydwilliams.com/2009/02/09/crowdsourcing-versus-citizen-science|archivedate=17 September 2014|df=}}</ref>
Compared to SETI@home, "Galaxy Zoo volunteers do real work. They're not just passively running something on their computer and hoping that they'll be the first person to find aliens. They have a stake in science that comes out of it, which means that they are now interested in what we do with it, and what we find."<ref name=AnthonyWilliams/>
Citizen policy may be another result of citizen science initiatives. Bethany Brookshire (pen name SciCurious) writes: "If citizens are going to live with the benefits or potential consequences of science (as the vast majority of them will), it's incredibly important to make sure that they are not only well informed about changes and advances in science and technology, but that they also ... are able to ... influence the science policy decisions that could impact their lives."<ref name=SciCur>{{cite web|title=Citizen Science, Citizen Policy|author=SciCurious|url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/scicurious-brain/citizen-science-citizen-policy/|publisher=Scientific American|date=7 January 2013|accessdate=23 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423064500/https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/scicurious-brain/citizen-science-citizen-policy/|archivedate=23 April 2017|df=}}</ref>
===Benefits and limitations===
In a research report published by the [[National Park Service]] in 2008, Brett Amy Thelen and Rachel K. Thiet mention the following concerns, previously reported in the literature, about the validity of volunteer-generated data:<ref name=Cape_Cod_CS>{{cite journal |url=http://www.nature.nps.gov/ParkScience/index.cfm?ArticleID=236&Page=1 |title=Cultivating connection: Incorporating meaningful citizen science into Cape Cod National Seashore's estuarine research and monitoring programs |author1=Thelen, Brett Amy |author2=Thiet, Rachel K. |journal=Park Science |volume=25 |issue=1 |year=2008 |ISSN=1090-9966 |publisher=ParkScience |accessdate=2012-10-11 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101174310/http://www.nature.nps.gov/ParkScience/index.cfm?ArticleID=236&Page=1 |archivedate=2014-01-01 |df= }}</ref> * Some projects may not be suitable for volunteers, for instance, when they use complex research methods or require arduous or repetitive work.<ref name=Cape_Cod_CS/> * If volunteers lack proper training in research and monitoring protocols, they are at risk of introducing bias into the data.<ref name=Cape_Cod_CS/> * Members may lie about data. This risk is even greater when bounties are awarded as an incentive to participate.<ref name=Cape_Cod_CS/>
The question of data accuracy, in particular, remains open.<ref name="Frías 2018">{{cite journal |last1=Frías |first1=O. |last2=Bautista |first2=L. M. |last3=Dénes |first3=F. V. |last4=Cuevas |first4=J. A. |last5= Martínez |first5=F. |last6=Blanco |first6=G. |year=2018 |title=Influence of habitat suitability and sex-related detectability on density and population size estimates of habitat-specialist warblers |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=13 |pages=020148 |url= http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article/file?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0201482&type=printable |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0201482}}</ref> John Losey, who created the [[Lost Ladybug Project|Lost Ladybug]] citizen science project, has argued that the cost-effectiveness of citizen science data can outweigh data quality issues, if properly managed.<ref name=LadyBeatles>{{cite journal|author1=M. M. Gardiner |author2=L. L. Allee |author3=P. M. J. Brown |author4=J. E. Losey |author5=H. E. Roy |author6=R. Rice Smyth |title=Lessons from lady beetles: accuracy of monitoring data from US and UK citizen-science programs|journal=[[Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment]]|date=November 2012|volume=10|doi=10.1890/110185 |pages=471–476}}</ref>
In December 2016, authors M. Kosmala, A. Wiggins, A. Swanson and B. Simmons published a study in the journal [[Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment]] called "Assessing Data Quality in Citizen Science".<ref name=ADQ>{{cite journal| author1=Margaret Kosmala| author2=Andrea Wiggins| author3=Alexandra Swanson| author4=Brooke Simmons| title=Assessing Data Quality in Citizen Science| journal=[[Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment]]| volume=14| issue=10| pages=551–560| date=1 December 2016| doi=10.1002/fee.1436}}</ref> The abstract describes how ecological and environmental CS projects have enormous potential to advance science. Also, CS projects can influence policy and guide resource management by producing [[dataset]]s that are otherwise infeasible to generate.<ref name=ADQ/> In the section "In a Nutshell" (pg3), four condensed conclusions are stated. They are:<ref name=ADQ/>
{{quote frame| # Datasets produced by volunteer CSs can have reliably high quality, on par with those produced by professionals. # Individual volunteer accuracy varies, depending on task difficulty and volunteer experience. Multiple methods exist for boosting accuracy to required levels for a given project. # Most types of [[bias]] found in CS datasets are also found in professionally produced datasets and can be accommodated using existing statistical tools. # Reviewers of CS projects should look for iterated project design, standardization and appropriateness of volunteer protocols and data analyses, capture of [[metadata]], and accuracy assessment. }}
They conclude that as CS continues to grow and mature, a key metric of project success they expect to see will be a growing awareness of data quality. They also conclude that CS will emerge as a general tool helping "to collect otherwise unobtainable high-quality data in support of policy and resource management, conservation monitoring, and basic science."<ref name=ADQ/>
A study of Canadian lepidoptera datasets published in 2018 compared the use of a professionally curated dataset of butterfly specimen records with four years of data from a CS program, [[eButterfly]]. <ref>{{cite news |last1=Semeniuk |first1=Ivan |title=The butterfly effect: How Canadians and their smartphones are helping scientists map species diversity |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/technology/science/article-the-butterfly-effect-how-canadians-and-their-smartphones-are-helping/ |accessdate=13 October 2018 |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date=7 October 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20181013040152/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/technology/science/article-the-butterfly-effect-how-canadians-and-their-smartphones-are-helping/ |archivedate=13 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Soroye |first1=Peter |last2=Ahmed |first2=Najeeba |last3=Kerr |first3=Jeremy T. |title=Opportunistic citizen science data transform understanding of species distributions, phenology, and diversity gradients for global change research |journal=Global Change Biology |date=3 July 2018 |doi=10.1111/gcb.14358 |url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/gcb.14358 |accessdate=13 October 2018}}</ref> The eButterfly dataset was used as it was determined to be of high quality because of the expert vetting process used on the site, and there existed a historic dataset covering the same geographic area consisting of specimen data, much of it institutional. The authors note that, in this case, CS data provides both novel and complementary information to the specimen data. Five new species were reported from the CS data, and geographic distribution information was improved for over 80% of species in the combined dataset when CS data was included.
====Law==== {{main article|Wyoming Senate Files 12 and 80 2015 'Trespassing To Collect Data'}} In March 2015, the state of [[Wyoming]] passed new laws (Senate Files 12 and 80) clarifying that trespassing laws applied even if the trespasser's intention was to gather data to further a U.S. government science program.<ref name=CourthouseNewsService>{{cite web|author=Emma Gannon|title=Wyoming Criminalizes Citizen Science|url=http://www.courthousenews.com/2015/05/18/wyoming-criminalizes-citizen-science.htm|publisher=Courthouse News Service|date=18 May 2015|accessdate=29 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160209050810/http://www.courthousenews.com/2015/05/18/wyoming-criminalizes-citizen-science.htm|archivedate=9 February 2016|df=}}</ref> This hampered some CS researchers who were collecting data while on other people's land.
==Ethics==
Various studies have been published that explore the [[ethics]] of CS, including issues such as [[intellectual property]] and project design.(e.g.<ref name=Re&Po/><ref name=Resnik_2015>{{cite journal|title=A framework for addressing ethical issues in citizen science|author1=D. B. Resnik|author2=K. C. Elliot|author3=A. K. Miller|journal=Environmental Science & Policy|volume=54|pages=475–481|date=December 2015|doi=10.1016/j.envsci.2015.05.008}}</ref><ref name=Bowser_2015>{{cite journal|title=Privacy in Participatory Research: Advancing Policy to support Human Computation|author1=A. E. Bowser|author2=A. Wiggins|journal=Human Computation|date=2015|pages=19–44|doi=10.1534/hc.v2i1.3}}</ref><ref name=Hoffman_2014>{{cite journal|title=Citizen Science: The Law and Ethics of Public Access to Medical Big Data|author=S. Hoffman|journal=Berkeley Technology Law Journal|date=September 2014|volume=Case Legal Studies Research Paper No. 2014-21}}</ref><ref name=Scassa_2015>{{cite web|title=Managing Intellectual Property Rights in Citizen Science: A Guide for Researchers and Citizen Scientists|author1=T. Scassa|author2=Chung H.|url=https://www.wilsoncenter.org/sites/default/files/managing_intellectual_property_rights_citizen_science_scassa_chung.pdf|publisher=Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars|date=2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170705153453/https://www.wilsoncenter.org/sites/default/files/managing_intellectual_property_rights_citizen_science_scassa_chung.pdf|archivedate=2017-07-05|df=}}</ref>) The Citizen Science Association (CSA), based at the [[Cornell Lab of Ornithology]], and the European Citizen Science Association (ECSA), based in the [[Museum für Naturkunde]] in Berlin, have working groups on ethics and principles.<ref name=CSA_1>{{cite web|title=CSA Working Group on Ethics|url=http://citizenscience.org/association/about/working-groups/ethics-working-group/|publisher=Citizen Science Association|accessdate=24 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825062443/http://citizenscience.org/association/about/working-groups/ethics-working-group/|archivedate=25 August 2017|df=}}</ref><ref name=ECSA_2>{{cite web|title=ECSA Principles & Standards in Citizen Science: Sharing Best Practice & Building Capacity|url=http://www.ecsa.citizen-science.net/taxonomy/term/205|publisher=ECSA|accessdate=18 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818072003/http://ecsa.citizen-science.net/taxonomy/term/205|archivedate=18 August 2016|df=}}</ref>
In September 2015, the European Citizen Science Association (ECSA) published its ''Ten Principles of Citizen Science'', which have been developed by the "Sharing best practice and building capacity" working group of the ECSA, led by the [[Natural History Museum, London]] with input from many members of the association.<ref name=ECSA_10>{{cite web|author=European Citizen Science Association|title=10 Principles of Citizen Science (English)|url=http://ecsa.citizen-science.net/sites/default/files/ecsa_ten_principles_of_citizen_science.pdf|publisher=ECSA|date=September 2015|accessdate=18 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822040236/http://ecsa.citizen-science.net/sites/default/files/ecsa_ten_principles_of_citizen_science.pdf|archivedate=22 August 2016|df=}}</ref><ref name=ECSA_Docs>{{cite web|title=ECSA Documents|url=http://ecsa.citizen-science.net/documents|publisher=ECSA|date=September 2015|access-date=18 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822042534/http://ecsa.citizen-science.net/documents|archivedate=22 August 2016|df=}}</ref> {{quote frame| # Citizen science projects actively involve citizens in scientific endeavour that generates new knowledge or understanding. Citizens may act as contributors, collaborators, or as project leader and have a meaningful role in the project. # Citizen science projects have a genuine science outcome. For example, answering a research question or informing conservation action, management decisions or environmental policy. # Both the professional scientists and the citizen scientists benefit from taking part. Benefits may include the publication of research outputs, learning opportunities, personal enjoyment, social benefits, satisfaction through contributing to scientific evidence e.g. to address local, national and international issues, and through that, the potential to influence policy. # Citizen scientists may, if they wish, participate in multiple stages of the scientific process. This may include developing the research question, designing the method, gathering and analysing data, and communicating the results. # Citizen scientists receive feedback from the project. For example, how their data are being used and what the research, policy or societal outcomes are. # Citizen science is considered a research approach like any other, with limitations and biases that should be considered and controlled for. However unlike traditional research approaches, citizen science provides opportunity for greater public engagement and democratisation of science. # Citizen science project data and meta-data are made publicly available and where possible, results are published in an open access format. Data sharing may occur during or after the project, unless there are security or privacy concerns that prevent this. # Citizen scientists are acknowledged in project results and publications. # Citizen science programmes are evaluated for their scientific output, data quality, participant experience and wider societal or policy impact. # The leaders of citizen science projects take into consideration legal and ethical issues surrounding copyright, intellectual property, data sharing agreements, confidentiality, attribution, and the environmental impact of any activities. }}
The medical ethics of internet crowdsourcing has been questioned by Graber & Graber in the [[Journal of Medical Ethics]].<ref name=Graber_1>{{cite journal|author1=M. A. Graber |author2=A. Graber |title=Internet-based crowdsourcing and research ethics:the case for IRB review|journal=The Journal of Medical Ethics|date=30 November 2012|doi=10.1136/medethics-2012-100798|volume=39|pages=115–118}}</ref> In particular, they analyse the effect of games and the crowdsourcing project [[Foldit]]. They conclude: "games can have possible adverse effects, and that they manipulate the user into participation".
===Economic worth===
In the research paper "Can citizen science enhance public understanding of science?" by Bonney et al. 2016,<ref name=Bonney&Phill>{{cite journal|title=Can citizen science enhance public understanding of science?|author1=R. Bonney|author2=T. B. Phillips|author3=H. L. Ballard|author4=J. W. Enck|journal=Public Understanding of Science|volume=25|issue=1|pages=2–16|doi=10.1177/0963662515607406|date=1 January 2016}}</ref> statistics which analyse the economic worth of citizen science are used, drawn from two papers: '''i)'''Sauermann and Franzoni 2015,<ref name=Sau&Fran>{{cite journal|title=Crowd science user contribution patterns and their implications|author1=Henry Sauermann|author2=Chiara Franzoni| journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America| volume=112|issue=3|pages=679–684|doi=10.1073/pnas.1408907112|date=20 January 2015|pmid=25561529|pmc=4311847|bibcode=2015PNAS..112..679S}}</ref> and '''ii)'''Theobald et al. 2015.<ref name=Theo&Ett>{{cite journal|title=Global change and local solutions: Tapping the unrealized potential of citizen science for biodiversity research|author1=J. Theobald|author2=A. K. Ettinger|author3=H. K. Burgess|author4=L. B. DeBey|author5=N. R. Schmidt|author6=H. E. Froehlich|author7=C. Wagner|author8=J. HilleRisLambers|author9=J. Tewksbury|author10=M. A. Harsch|author11=J. K. Parrish|journal=Biological Conservation|volume=181|issue=2015|pages=236–244|date=1 January 2015|doi=10.1016/j.biocon.2014.10.021}}</ref> In "Crowd science user contribution patterns and their implications" by Sauermann and Franzoni (2015), seven projects from the Zooniverse web portal are used to estimate the monetary value of the CS that had taken place. The 7 projects are: Solar Stormwatch, Galaxy Zoo Supernovae, Galaxy Zoo Hubble, Moon Zoo, Old Weather, The Milky Way Project and Planet Hunters.<ref name=Sau&Fran/> Using data from 180 days in 2010, they find a total of 100,386 users participated, contributing 129,540 hours of unpaid work.<ref name=Sau&Fran/> Estimating at a rate of $12 an hour (an undergraduate research assistant's basic wage), the total contributions amount to $1,554,474, an average of $222,068 per project.<ref name=Sau&Fran/> It should be noted that the range over the 7 projects was from $22,717 to $654,130.<ref name=Sau&Fran/>
In "Global change and local solutions: Tapping the unrealized potential of citizen science for biodiversity research" by Theobald et al. 2015, the authors surveyed 388 unique biodiversity-based projects.<ref name=Theo&Ett/> Quoting: "We estimate that between 1.36 million and 2.28 million people volunteer annually in the 388 projects we surveyed, though variation is great" and that "the range of in-kind contribution of the volunteerism in our 388 citizen science projects as between $667 million to $2.5 billion annually."<ref name=Theo&Ett/>
Worldwide participation in citizen science continues to grow. A list of the top five citizen science communities compiled by [[Marc Kuchner]] and Kristen Erickson in July 2018 shows a total of 3.75 million participants, although there is likely substantial overlap between the communities. [[File:Citizen Science Communities.jpg|thumb|Five top citizen science communities as of July 1, 2018.]]

Some examples of studies are:
From the Second International Handbook of Science Education, a chapter entitled: "Citizen Science, Ecojustice, and Science Education: Rethinking an Education from Nowhere" by Mueller and Tippins (2011), acknowledges in the abstract that: "There is an emerging emphasis in science education on engaging youth in citizen science." The authors also ask: "whether citizen science goes further with respect to citizen development."<ref name=CS_Eco/> The abstract ends by stating that the "chapter takes account of the ways educators will collaborate with members of the community to effectively guide decisions, which offers promise for sharing a responsibility for democratizing science with others."<ref name=CS_Eco>{{cite book| title=Citizen Science, Ecojustice, and Science Education: Rethinking an Education from Nowhere| author1=M.P. Mueller| author2=D.J. Tippins| publisher=Springer International Handbooks of Education| volume=24|date=23 November 2011| doi=10.1007/978-1-4020-9041-7_58| isbn=978-1-4020-9040-0}}</ref>
From the journal Democracy and Education, an article entitled: "Lessons Learned from Citizen Science in the Classroom" by authors Gray, Nicosia and Jordan (GNJ) (2012) give a response to a study by Mueller, Tippins and Bryan (MTB) called "The Future of Citizen Science".<ref name=DemEdu>{{cite journal| title=Lessons Learned from Citizen Science in the Classroom| author1=S.A. Gray| author2=K. Nicosia| author3=R.C.
