Mueller| author2=D. Tippins| author3=L.A. Bryan| journal=Democracy and Education| volume=20| issue=1| date=2012}}</ref> GNJ begins by stating in the abstract that the study The Future Of Citizen Science: "provides an important theoretical perspective about the future of democratized science and [[K–12|K12]] education." But GRB state: "However, the authors (MTB) fail to adequately address the existing barriers and constraints to moving community-based science into the classroom." They end the abstract by arguing: "that the resource constraints of scientists, teachers, and students likely pose problems to moving true democratized science into the classroom."<ref name=DemEdu/>
In 2014, a study was published called "Citizen Science and Lifelong Learning" by R. Edwards in the journal Studies in the Education of Adults.<ref name=CSLL>{{cite journal| title=Citizen Science and Lifelong Learning| author=R. Edwards| journal=Studies in the Education of Adults| volume=46| number=2| pages=132–144| date=2014| issn=0266-0830| doi=10.1080/02660830.2014.11661662}}</ref> Edwards begins by writing in the abstract that CS projects have expanded over recent years and engaged CSs and professionals in diverse ways. He continues: "Yet there has been little educational exploration of such projects to date."<ref name=CSLL/> He describes that "there has been limited exploration of the educational backgrounds of adult contributors to citizen science". Edwards explains that CS contributers are referred to as volunteers, citizens or as amateurs. He ends the abstract: "The article will explore the nature and significance of these different characterisations and also suggest possibilities for further research."<ref name=CSLL/>
In the journal Microbiology and Biology Education a study was published by Shah and Martinez (2015) called "Current Approaches in Implementing Citizen Science in the Classroom".<ref name=CurrApp>{{cite journal| title=Current Approaches in Implementing Citizen Science in the Classroom| author1=H.R. Shah| author2=L.R. Martinez| journal=Microbiology & Biology Education| date=March 2015| volume=17| issue=1| doi=10.1128/jmbe.v17i1.1032| pages=17–22}}</ref> They begin by writing in the abstract that CS is a partnership between inexperienced amateurs and trained scientists. The authors continue: "With recent studies showing a weakening in scientific competency of American students, incorporating citizen science initiatives in the curriculum provides a means to address deficiencies".<ref name=CurrApp/> They argue that combining traditional and innovative methods can help provide a practical experience of science. The abstract ends: "Citizen science can be used to emphasize the recognition and use of systematic approaches to solve problems affecting the community."<ref name=CurrApp/>
In November 2017, authors Mitchell, Triska and Liberatore published a study in [[PLOS|Public Library of Science]] titled "Benefits and Challenges of Incorporating Citizen Science into University Education".<ref name=Bene&Chall>{{cite journal| title=Benefits and Challenges of Incorporating Citizen Science into University Education| author1=N. Mitchell| author2=M. Triska| author3=A. Liberatore| author4=L. Ashcroft| author5=R. Weatherill| author6=N. Longnecker| journal=[[Public Library of Science]]| url=https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0186285| date=1 November 2017| access-date=21 January 2018| doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0186285| volume=12| page=e0186285| bibcode=2017PLoSO..1286285M}}</ref> The authors begin by stating in the abstract that CSs contribute data with the expectation that it will be used. It reports that CS has been used for first year university students as a means to experience research. They continue: "Surveys of more than 1500 students showed that their environmental engagement increased significantly after participating in data collection and data analysis."<ref name=Bene&Chall/> However, only a third of students agreed that data collected by CSs was reliable. A positive outcome of this was that the students were more careful of their own research. The abstract ends: "If true for citizen scientists in general, enabling participants as well as scientists to analyse data could enhance data quality, and so address a key constraint of broad-scale citizen science programs."<ref name=Bene&Chall/>
== History ==
"Citizen science" is a fairly new term but an old practice. Prior to the 20th century, science was often the pursuit of [[gentleman scientist]]s, amateur or self-funded researchers such as Sir [[Isaac Newton]], [[Benjamin Franklin]], and [[Charles Darwin]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Silvertown | first1 = J | year = 2009 | title = A new dawn for citizen science | url = | journal = Trends in Ecology and Evolution | volume = 24 | issue = 9| pages = 467–471 | doi=10.1016/j.tree.2009.03.017}}</ref> By the mid-20th century, however, science was dominated by researchers employed by universities and government research laboratories. By the 1970s, this transformation was being called into question. Philosopher [[Paul Feyerabend]] called for a "democratization of science".<ref>{{cite book |author=Paul Feyerabend |author-link=Paul Feyerabend |title=Science in a free society |publisher=[[New Left Books]]|location=London |year=1982 |pages= |isbn=0-86091-753-3 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> Biochemist [[Erwin Chargaff]] advocated a return to science by nature-loving amateurs in the tradition of [[René Descartes|Descartes]], Newton, [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz|Leibniz]], [[Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon|Buffon]], and [[Charles Darwin|Darwin]]—science dominated by "amateurship instead of money-biased technical bureaucrats".<ref>{{cite book |author=Erwin Chargaff |author-link=Erwin Chargaff |title=Heraclitean fire: sketches from a life before nature |publisher=[[Rockefeller University Press]] |location=New York |year=1978 |pages= |isbn=0-87470-029-9 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref>
A study from 2016 indicates that the largest impact of citizen science is in research on biology, conservation and ecology, and is utilized mainly as a methodology of collecting and classifying data.<ref name=kullberg>{{cite journal|author1=C. Kullenberg |author2=D. Kasperowski |title=What Is Citizen Science? – A Scientometric Meta-Analysis|journal=PLoS ONE|date=14 January 2016|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0147152|volume=11|pages=e0147152|pmid=26766577|pmc=4713078|bibcode=2016PLoSO..1147152K}}</ref>
===Amateur astronomy=== {{main article|Amateur astronomy}} [[File:Telescope trailer 22.jpg|right|thumb|250px|upright|Amateur astronomers can build their own equipment and can hold star parties and gatherings, such as [[Stellafane]].]]
[[Astronomy]] has long been a field where amateurs have contributed throughout time, all the way up to the present day.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Mims III |first=Forrest M. |authorlink=Forrest Mims |title=Amateur Science—Strong Tradition, Bright Future |journal=Science |year=1999 |volume=284 |issue=5411 |pages=55–56 |doi=10.1126/science.284.5411.55 |quote=Astronomy has traditionally been among the most fertile fields for serious amateurs [...] |bibcode = 1999Sci...284...55M}}</ref>
Collectively, amateur astronomers observe a variety of celestial objects and phenomena sometimes with [[Amateur telescope making|equipment that they build themselves]]. Common targets of amateur astronomers include the Moon, planets, stars, comets, meteor showers, and a variety of [[deep-sky object]]s such as star clusters, galaxies, and nebulae. Observations of comets and stars are also used to measure the local level of [[skyglow|artificial skyglow]].<ref name="GaN">{{cite journal|last=Kyba|first=Christopher C. M.|author2=Wagner, Janna M. |author3=Kuechly, Helga U. |author4=Walker, Constance E. |author5=Elvidge, Christopher D. |author6=Falchi, Fabio |author7=Ruhtz, Thomas |author8=Fischer, Jürgen |author9= Hölker, Franz |title=Citizen Science Provides Valuable Data for Monitoring Global Night Sky Luminance|journal=[[Scientific Reports]]|volume=3|doi=10.1038/srep01835|bibcode = 2013NatSR...3E1835K |date=2013 |pmid=23677222 |pmc=3655480}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Sciezor |first1 = T. |doi = 10.1093/mnras/stt1297 |title = A new astronomical method for determining the brightness of the night sky and its application to study long-term changes in the level of light pollution |journal = [[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] |volume = 435 |pages = 303–310 |year = 2013 |pmid = |pmc = |bibcode = 2013MNRAS.435..303S}}</ref> One branch of amateur astronomy, amateur [[astrophotography]], involves the taking of photos of the night sky. Many amateurs like to specialize in the observation of particular objects, types of objects, or types of events that interest them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amsmeteors.org/|title = The Americal Meteor Society|accessdate =24 August 2006|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060822135040/http://www.amsmeteors.org/|archivedate= 22 August 2006 <!-- DASHBot -->|deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Jerry|last=Lodriguss|url=http://www.astropix.com/|title = Catching the Light: Astrophotography|accessdate =24 August 2006|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060901185541/http://www.astropix.com/|archivedate= 1 September 2006 <!-- DASHBot -->|deadurl= no}}</ref>
The [[American Association of Variable Star Observers]] has gathered data on variable stars for educational and professional analysis since 1911 and promotes participation beyond its membership on its Citizen Sky website.<ref name=CSP>{{cite journal| author1=A. Price| author2=R. Turner| author3=R.E. Stencel| author4=B.K. Kloppenborg| author5=A.A. Henden| title=The Origins and Future of the Citizen Sky Project| journal=[[Journal of the American Association of Variable Star Observers]]| date=12 June 2012| volume=40| pages=614–617}}</ref>
===Butterfly counts=== {{main article|Butterfly count}} Butterfly counts have a long tradition of involving individuals in the study of butterflies' range and their relative abundance. Two long-running programs are the UK Butterfly Monitoring Scheme (started in 1976) and the [[North American Butterfly Association]]'s Butterfly Count Program (started in 1975).<ref name=UKBMS>{{cite web|title=The UK Butterfly Monitoring Scheme (UKBMS)|url=http://www.ukbms.org|accessdate=29 December 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141230125155/http://www.ukbms.org/|archivedate=30 December 2014|df=}}</ref><ref name=NABA_BCD>{{cite web|author=Leslie Ries|title=Analyzing the NABA Butterfly Count Data|url=http://www.naba.org/pubs/ab141/ab141count_column.pdf|accessdate=29 December 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161223114316/http://www.naba.org/pubs/ab141/ab141count_column.pdf|archivedate=23 December 2016|df=}}</ref> There are various protocols for monitoring butterflies and different organizations support one or more of transects, counts and/or opportunistic sightings.<ref name=NA_Goal>{{cite web|title=Goal 1: Track all North American butterfly monitoring|url=http://www.nab-net.org/goal-1|accessdate=29 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141230133120/http://www.nab-net.org/goal-1|archivedate=30 December 2014|df=}}</ref> [[eButterfly]] is an example of a program designed to capture any of the three types of counts for observers in North America. Species-specific programs also exist, with monarchs the prominent example.<ref name=E_ButtHP>{{cite web|title=eButterfly Homepage|url=http://www.e-butterfly.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140408031027/http://www.e-butterfly.org/|archivedate=2014-04-08|df=}}</ref> Two examples of this involve the counting of monarch butterflies during the fall [[Monarch butterfly migration|migration]] to overwintering sites in Mexico: (1) Monarch Watch is a continent-wide project, while (2) the Cape May Monarch Monitoring Project is an example of a local project.<ref name=MW_HP>{{cite web|title=Monarch Watch Homepage|url=http://www.monarchwatch.org|accessdate=1 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=CS_MonarchButterfly>{{cite web|title=The Cape May Monarch Monitoring Project|publisher=New Jersey Audubon Research Department, and the Cape May Bird Observatory|url=http://www.monarchmonitoringproject.com/index.html|accessdate=4 October 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006123918/http://www.monarchmonitoringproject.com/index.html|archivedate=6 October 2014|df=}}</ref> The Austrian project [http://viel-falter.at Viel-Falter] investigated if and how trained and supervised pupils are able to systematically collect data about the occurrence of diurnal butterflies, and how this data could contribute to a permanent butterfly monitoring system. Despite substantial identification uncertainties for some species or species groups, the data collected by pupils was successfully used to predict the general habitat quality for butterflies.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rüdisser|first=Johannes|last2=Tasser|first2=Erich|last3=Walde|first3=Janette|last4=Huemer|first4=Peter|last5=Lechner|first5=Kurt|last6=Ortner|first6=Alois|last7=Tappeiner|first7=Ulrike|date=2017-08-01|title=Simplified and still meaningful: assessing butterfly habitat quality in grasslands with data collected by pupils|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10841-017-0010-3|journal=Journal of Insect Conservation|language=en|volume=21|issue=4|pages=677–688|doi=10.1007/s10841-017-0010-3|issn=1366-638X}}</ref>
===Ornithology=== {{main article|Birdwatching}} Citizen science projects have become increasingly focused on providing benefits to scientific research.<ref>Bonney, R. and LaBranche, M. (2004). Citizen Science: Involving the Public in Research. ASTC Dimensions. May/June 2004, p. 13.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Baretto | first1 = C. | last2 = Fastovsky | first2 = D. | last3 = Sheehan | first3 = P. | year = 2003 | title = A Model for Integrating the Public into Scientific Research | url = | journal = [[Journal of Geoscience Education]] | volume = 50 | issue = 1| pages = 71–75 }}</ref><ref>McCaffrey, R.E. (2005). Using Citizen Science in Urban Bird Studies. Urban Habitats. 3 (1). p. 70-86.</ref> The [[North American Bird Phenology Program]] (historically called the Bird Migration and Distribution records) may have been the earliest collective effort of citizens collecting ornithological information in the U.S.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pwrc.usgs.gov/bpp/|title=North American Phenology Program|publisher=|accessdate=30 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160729190651/http://www.pwrc.usgs.gov/bpp/|archivedate=29 July 2016|df=}}</ref> The program, dating back to 1883, was started by Wells Woodbridge Cooke. Cooke established a network of observers around North America to collect bird migration records. The [[National Audubon Society|Audubon Society]]'s [[Christmas Bird Count]], which began in 1900, is another example of a long-standing tradition of citizen science which has persisted to the present day. Citizen scientists help gather data that will be analyzed by professional researchers, and can be used to produce bird population and biodiversity indicators.
Raptor migration research relies on the data collected by the [[hawkwatching]] community. This mostly volunteer group counts migrating accipiters, buteos, falcons, harriers, kites, eagles, osprey, vultures and other raptors at hawk sites throughout North America during the spring and fall seasons.<ref>{{Cite book|title="Bird!": An Exploration of Hawkwatching|last=Wargo|first=Brian M.|publisher=BMW Endeavors, LLC|year=2016|isbn=978-1-945226-00-7|location=McKees Rocks|pages=}}</ref> The daily data is uploaded to hawkcount.org where it can be viewed by professional scientists and the public.
Such indices can be useful tools to inform management, resource allocation, policy and planning.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Devictor | first1 = V. | last2 = Whittaker | first2 = R. J. | last3 = Bel trame | first3 = C. | year = 2010 | title = Beyond scarcity: citizen science programmes as useful tools for conservation biogeography | url = | journal = Diversity and Distributions | volume = 16 | issue = | pages = 354–362 | doi=10.1111/j.1472-4642.2009.00615.x}}</ref> For example, European breeding bird survey data provide input for the Farmland Bird Index, adopted by the European Union as a structural indicator of sustainable development.<ref>Jiguet, F., Devictor, V., Jul iard, R. & Couvet, D. 2012. "French citizens monitoring ordinary birds provide tools for conservation and ecological sciences". Acta Oecologica-International Journal of Ecology, 44, 58–66.</ref> This provides a cost-effective alternative to government monitoring.
Similarly, data collected by citizen scientists as part of BirdLife Australia's has been analysed to produce the first-ever Australian Terrestrial Bird Indices.<ref>{{cite web|title=Australian birdlife|url=http://birdlife.org.au/state-of-birds|accessdate=30 December 2015|date=16 July 2014}}</ref>
=== Citizen oceanography === The concept of citizen science has been extended to the ocean environment for characterizing ocean dynamics and tracking [[marine debris]]. For example, the mobile app Marine Debris Tracker is a joint partnership of [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] and the [[University of Georgia]].<ref name=MDT>{{cite web| title=Marine Debris Tracker| publisher=Marine Debris Tracker| url=http://www.marinedebris.engr.uga.edu| access-date=19 March 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171227041320/http://www.marinedebris.engr.uga.edu/| archivedate=27 December 2017| df=}}</ref> Long term sampling efforts such as the [[Continuous Plankton Recorder|continuous plankton recorder]] has been fitted on ships of opportunity since 1931. Plankton collection by sailors and subsequent genetic analysis was pioneered in 2013 by Indigo V Expeditions as a way to better understand marine microbial structure and function.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Common Oceanographer: Crowdsourcing the Collection of Oceanographic Data|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.1001947|journal = PLoS Biol|date = 2014-09-09|pmc = 4159111|pmid = 25203659|pages = e1001947|volume = 12|issue = 9|doi = 10.1371/journal.pbio.1001947|first = Federico M.|last = Lauro|first2 = Svend Jacob|last2 = Senstius|first3 = Jay|last3 = Cullen|first4 = Russell|last4 = Neches|first5 = Rachelle M.|last5 = Jensen|first6 = Mark V.|last6 = Brown|first7 = Aaron E.|last7 = Darling|first8 = Michael|last8 = Givskov|first9 = Diane|last9 = McDougald}}</ref>
=== Citizen study of coral reefs === Citizen science has recently developed in [[Coral reef]] studies.
[[Underwater photography]] has become more and more popular since the early 2000s, resulting on millions of pictures posted every year on various websites and social media. This mass of documentation is endowed with an enormous scientific potential, as millions of tourists possess a much superior coverage power than professional scientists, who can not allow themselves to spend so much time in the field. As a consequence, several participative sciences programs have been developped, supported by geo-localization and identification web sites (such as [https://www.inaturalist.org/ iNaturalist.org]). Another example, the ''Monitoring through many eyes'' project collates thousands of underwater images of the [[Great Barrier Reef]] and provides an interface for elicitation of reef health indicators.<ref name=MTME>{{cite web|title=Monitoring through many eyes project homepage|url=https://www.virtualreef.org.au|publisher=Queensland Government, Queensland University of Technology, CRCSI|accessdate=10 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170301205255/https://www.virtualreef.org.au/|archivedate=1 March 2017|df=}}</ref>
Additionally, the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] offers opportunities for volunteer participation. By taking measurements in [[United States National Marine Sanctuary|The United States' National Marine Sanctuaries]], citizens are able to contribute data to a variety of [[marine biology]] projects. By enabling these citizens, [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]] benefited from 137,000 hours of research during 2016.<ref name=MTME_2>{{cite web| title=Volunteers help to ensure national marine sanctuaries remain America's underwater treasures for future generations| url=https://sanctuaries.noaa.gov/involved/volunteer_future.html| publisher=National Ocean Servi, NOAA, Department of Commerce| accessdate=5 September 2017| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170906034716/https://sanctuaries.noaa.gov/involved/volunteer_future.html| archivedate=6 September 2017| df=}}</ref>
There also exist protocols for auto-organization and self-teaching aimed at biodiversity-interested snorkelers, in order for them to turn their observations into sound scientific data, available for research. This kind of approach has been successfully used in [[Réunion island]], allowing for tens of new records and even new species<ref name="CBM2018">{{cite journal |last1=Bourjon |first1=Philippe |last2=Ducarme |first2=Frédéric |last3=Quod |first3=Jean-Pascal |last4=Sweet |first4=Michael |year=2018 |title=Involving recreational snorkelers in inventory improvement or creation: a case study in the Indian Ocean |url=http://application.sb-roscoff.fr/cbm/article.htm?execution=e2s1 |journal=Cahiers de Biologie Marine |volume=59 |issue= |pages=451 - 460 |doi=10.21411/CBM.A.B05FC714 |access-date= }}</ref>.
=== Art history === Citizen science has a long tradition in [[Natural science]]. But nowadays, citizen science projects can also be found in various fields of science like [[Art history]]. For example, the [[Zooniverse (citizen science project)|Zooniverse]] project AnnoTate is a transcription tool developed to enable volunteers to read and transcribe the personal papers of British-born and émigré artists.<ref name=AnnoTate>{{cite web|title=AnnoTate homepage|url=https://anno.tate.org.uk|publisher=Zooniverse|accessdate=2 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160507142819/https://anno.tate.org.uk/|archivedate=7 May 2016|df=}}</ref> The papers are drawn from the [[Tate Britain|Tate Archive]]. Another example of citizen science in art history is [[Human-based computation game#Artigo|ARTigo]].<ref name=Artigo>{{cite web|title=ARTigo homepage|url=http://www.artigo.org|publisher=ARTigo|accessdate=2 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160601154649/http://www.artigo.org/|archivedate=1 June 2016|df=}}</ref> ARTigo collects [[Semantics|semantic]] data on artworks from the footprints left by players of games featuring artwork images. From these footprints, ARTigo automatically builds a [[semantic search]] engine for artworks.
===Modern technology=== Newer technologies have increased the options for citizen science.<ref name=BBC_NewEra>{{cite web|author=Dan Drollette|title=Citizen science enters a new era|url=http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120329-citizen-science-enters-a-new-era?selectorSection=technology|publisher=BBC|date=29 March 2012|accessdate=4 October 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018015022/http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120329-citizen-science-enters-a-new-era?selectorSection=technology|archivedate=18 October 2014|df=}}</ref> Citizen scientists can build and operate their own instruments to gather data for their own experiments or as part of a larger project. Examples include [[amateur radio]], [[amateur astronomy]], Six Sigma Projects, and [[Maker culture|Maker]] activities. Most recently scientist [[Joshua Pearce]] has advocated for the creation of [[open-source hardware]] based scientific equipment that both citizen scientists and professional scientists, which can be replicated by [[digital manufacturing]] techniques such as [[3D printing]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Pearce|first = Joshua M.|date = 2012-09-14|title = Building Research Equipment with Free, Open-Source Hardware|url = http://science.sciencemag.org/content/337/6100/1303|journal = Science|language = en|volume = 337|issue = 6100|pages = 1303–1304|doi = 10.1126/science.1228183|issn = 0036-8075|pmid = 22984059|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160310180623/http://science.sciencemag.org/content/337/6100/1303|archivedate = 2016-03-10|df = |bibcode = 2012Sci...337.1303P}}</ref> Multiple studies have shown this approach radically reduces scientific equipment costs.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Pearce|first = J. M.|date = 2015-06-20|title = Return on investment for open source scientific hardware development|url= https://www.academia.edu/13799962/Return_on_Investment_for_Open_Source_Hardware_Development|journal = Science and Public Policy|language = en|pages = scv034|doi = 10.1093/scipol/scv034|issn = 0302-3427|volume=43}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last = Baden|first = Tom|last2 = Chagas|first2 = Andre Maia|last3 = Gage|first3 = Greg|last4 = Marzullo|first4 = Timothy|last5 = Prieto-Godino|first5 = Lucia L.|last6 = Euler|first6 = Thomas|title = Open Labware: 3-D Printing Your Own Lab Equipment|url = http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.1002086|journal = PLOS Biology|volume = 13|issue = 3|doi = 10.1371/journal.pbio.1002086|pmc = 4368627|pmid = 25794301|pages=e1002086|year=2015}}</ref> Examples of this approach include water testing, nitrate and other environmental testing, basic biology and optics.<ref name=":0"/><ref name=":1">{{cite web|url = https://publiclab.org/|title = Public Lab: a DIY environmental science community|last = Contributors|first = Public Lab|website = publiclab.org|access-date = 2016-02-27|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160226073149/https://publiclab.org/|archivedate = 2016-02-26|df = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last = Damase|first = Tulsi R.|last2 = Stephens|first2 = Daniel|last3 = Spencer|first3 = Adam|last4 = Allen|first4 = Peter B.|title = Open source and DIY hardware for DNA nanotechnology labs|url = http://www.jbmethods.org/jbm/article/view/72|journal = Journal of Biological Methods|volume = 2|issue = 3|doi = 10.14440/jbm.2015.72|pmc = 4598940|pmid = 26457320|page = 24|year = 2015|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160301212240/http://www.jbmethods.org/jbm/article/view/72|archivedate = 2016-03-01|df = }}</ref><ref name=Zhang_1>{{cite journal| title=Open-Source 3D-Printable Optics Equipment| author1=C. Zhang| author2=N.C. Anzalone| author3=R.P. Faria| author4=J.M. Pearce| journal=PLoS ONE| date=27 March 2013| url=https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0059840| volume=8| issue=3}}</ref> Groups such as Public Labs, which is a community where citizen scientists can learn how to investigate environmental concerns using inexpensive [[Do it yourself|DIY]] techniques, embody this approach.<ref name=":1"/>
[[File:Citizen Science Center NCMNS.jpg|thumb|300px|Citizen Science Center exhibit in the Nature Research Center wing of the [[North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences]]]]
Video technology has enabled expanded citizen science.{{Citation needed|date=October 2014}} The Citizen Science Center in the [[Nature Research Center#First floor 2|Nature Research Center]] wing of the [[North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences]] has exhibits on how to get involved in scientific research and become a citizen scientist. For example, visitors can observe birdfeeders at the [[North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences#Prairie Ridge Ecostation|Prairie Ridge Ecostation]] satellite facility via live video feed and record which species they see.
Since 2005, the [[Genographic Project]] has used the latest genetic technology to expand our knowledge of the human story, and its pioneering use of DNA testing to engage and involve the public in the research effort has helped to create a new breed of "citizen scientist". Geno 2.0 expands the scope for citizen science, harnessing the power of the [[Crowdsourcing|crowd]] to discover new details of human population history.<ref name=Wells>{{cite web|last = Wells|first = Spencer|title = The Genographic Project and the Rise of Citizen Science|publisher = Southern California Genealogical Society (SCGS)|year = 2013|url = http://www.scgsgenealogy.com/Jamboree/2013/DNAday.htm|accessdate = July 10, 2013|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130710014353/http://www.scgsgenealogy.com/Jamboree/2013/DNAday.htm|archivedate = July 10, 2013|df = }}</ref> This includes supporting, organization and dissemination of [[Genealogical DNA test|personal DNA (genetic) testing.]] Like [[Amateur astronomy]], citizen scientists encouraged by volunteer organizations like the [[International Society of Genetic Genealogy]] have provided valuable information and research to the professional scientific community.<ref name=KingJobling>{{cite journal|last1=King|doi=10.1016/j.tig.2009.06.003|quote=The International Society of Genetic Genealogy <http://www.isogg.org> advocates the use of genetics as a tool for genealogical research, and provides a support network for genetic genealogists. It hosts the ISOGG Y-haplogroup tree, which has the virtue of being regularly updated.|title=What's in a name? Y chromosomes, surnames and the genetic genealogy revolution|year=2009|first1=Turi E.|last2=Jobling|first2=Mark A.|journal=Trends in Genetics|volume=25|issue=8|pages=351–60|pmid=19665817|url=https://lra.le.ac.uk/bitstream/2381/8106/1/KingJoblingRevisedWeb.pdf}}</ref><ref name=AJHG>{{cite journal |last = Mendex, etc. al. |first = Fernando |title = An African American Paternal Lineage Adds an Extremely Ancient Root to the Human Y Chromosome Phylogenetic Tree |date=February 28, 2013 |publisher = The American Society of Human Genetics |url = http://www.cell.com/AJHG/abstract/S0002-9297%2813%2900073-6 |accessdate = July 10, 2013 |doi=10.1016/j.ajhg.2013.02.002 |volume=92 |journal=The American Journal of Human Genetics |pages=454–459}} This is volume 92, issue 3, pages 454–459.</ref>
With [[unmanned aerial vehicle]]s, further citizen science is enabled. One example is the [[European Space Agency|ESA's]] AstroDrone smartphone app for gathering robotic data with the [[Parrot AR.Drone]].<ref name=AsDr>{{cite web| title=Astro Drone - A Crowdsourcing Game to Improve Visual Algorithms| url=http://www.esa.int/gsp/ACT/ai/projects/astrodrone.html| publisher=[[European Space Agency]]| access-date=17 January 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171111042331/http://www.esa.int/gsp/ACT/ai/projects/astrodrone.html| archivedate=11 November 2017| df=}}</ref>
Citizens in Space (CIS), a project of the United States Rocket Academy, seeks to combine citizen science with citizen space exploration.<ref name=Citizens_In_Space>{{cite web|title=Citizens In Space|url=http://www.citizensinspace.org|publisher=Citizensinspace|accessdate=15 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140827233150/http://www.citizensinspace.org/|archivedate=27 August 2014|df=}}</ref> CIS is training citizen astronauts to fly as payload operators on suborbital reusable spacecraft that are now in development. CIS will also be developing, and encouraging others to develop, citizen-science payloads to fly on suborbital vehicles. CIS has already acquired a contract for 10 flights on the Lynx suborbital vehicle, being developed by [[XCOR Aerospace]], and plans to acquire additional flights on [[XCOR Lynx]] and other suborbital vehicles in the future.<ref name=Citizens_In_Space/>
CIS believes that "The development of low-cost reusable suborbital spacecraft will be the next great enabler, allowing citizens to participate in space exploration and space science."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.citizensinspace.org/2012/02/teachers-in-space-becomes-citizens-in-space-2/ |title="Teachers in Space" becomes "Citizens In Space" |publisher=Citizensinspace.org |accessdate=2012-11-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026131929/http://www.citizensinspace.org/2012/02/teachers-in-space-becomes-citizens-in-space-2/ |archivedate=2012-10-26 |df= }}</ref>
===Internet===
[[File:SAH stopmo 1.webm|thumb|How your gameplay helps [[ScienceAtHome]] build a quantum computer]]
The Internet has been a boon to citizen science, particularly through [[gamification]].<ref name=BBC_NewEra/> One of the first Internet-based citizen science experiments was [[NASA]]'s [[Clickworkers]], which enabled the general public to assist in the classification of images, greatly reducing the time to analyze large data sets. Another was the Citizen Science Toolbox, launched in 2003, of the Australian Coastal Collaborative Research Centre.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://research.usc.edu.au/vital/access/manager/Repository/usc:1413|title=The Citizen Science Toolbox : Citizen Science: Linking communities, scientists and decision-makers|first1=J.|last1=Fien|first2=T. F.|last2=Smith|last3=Lazarow|first3=N. S.|last4=Pembleton|first4=J.|last5=Rosenthal|first5=K|last6=Alcock|first6=D.|last7=Thomsen|first7=D. C.|last8=Hudson|first8=K.|last9=Gleeson|first9=J.|last10=Oliver|first10=P.|last11=Gooch|first11=M.|last12=White|first12=C.|last13=Powell|first13=B.|last14=Whelan|first14=J.|last15=Rickson|first15=R.|last16=Eisner|first16=R.|last17=Dwyer|first17=D.|last18=Malawkin|first18=H.|last19=Tilden|first19=J.|date=1 January 2003|publisher=|accessdate=30 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160809170858/http://research.usc.edu.au/vital/access/manager/Repository/usc:1413|archivedate=9 August 2016|df=}}</ref> Mozak is a game in which players create 3D reconstructions from images of actual human and mouse neurons, helping to advance understanding of the brain. One of the largest citizen science games is [[Eyewire]], a brain-mapping puzzle game developed at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] that now has over 200,000 players.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tinati|first1=Ramine|last2=Luczak-Roesch|first2=Markus|last3=Simperl|first3=Elena|last4=Hall|first4=Wendy|title=Because science is awesome: studying participation in a citizen science game|journal=Proceedings of the 8th ACM Conference on Web Science|date=2016|pages=45–54|doi=10.1145/2908131.2908151}}</ref> Another example is [[Quantum Moves]], a game developed by the Center for Driven Community Research at [[Aarhus University]], which uses online community efforts to solve quantum physics problems.<ref name=SCAH>{{cite web| title=Science At Home - About Us| url=https://www.scienceathome.org/about-us| publisher=Science at Home| access-date=17 January 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170518221342/https://www.scienceathome.org/about-us/| archivedate=18 May 2017| df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://phys.au.dk/en/research/research-areas/coder/|title=CODER - AU Ideas Center for Community Driven Research|author=20156@au.dk|work=au.dk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911161608/http://phys.au.dk/en/research/research-areas/coder/|archivedate=2017-09-11|df=}}</ref> The solutions found by players can then be used in the lab to feed computational algorithms used in building a scalable [[Quantum computing|quantum computer]].
More generally, Amazon's [[Amazon Mechanical Turk|Mechanical Turk]] is frequently used in the creation, collection, and processing of data by paid citizens.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/inside-amazons-hidden-science-factory/|title=The Internet's hidden science factory|work=PBS NewsHour|access-date=2017-09-11|language=en-US|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911114807/http://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/inside-amazons-hidden-science-factory/|archivedate=2017-09-11|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bohannon|first=John|date=2016-06-10|title=Mechanical Turk upends social sciences|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/352/6291/1263|journal=Science|language=en|volume=352|issue=6291|pages=1263–1264|doi=10.1126/science.352.6291.1263|issn=0036-8075|pmid=27284175|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911115432/http://science.sciencemag.org/content/352/6291/1263|archivedate=2017-09-11|df=}}</ref> There is controversy as to whether or not the data collected through such services is reliable, as it is subject to participants' desire for compensation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guilty-planet/httpblogsscientificamericancomguilty-planet20110707the-pros-cons-of-amazon-mechanical-turk-for-scientific-surveys/|title=The pros & cons of Amazon Mechanical Turk for scientific surveys|last=Jacquet|first=Jennifer|work=Scientific American Blog Network|access-date=2017-09-11|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911163048/https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guilty-planet/httpblogsscientificamericancomguilty-planet20110707the-pros-cons-of-amazon-mechanical-turk-for-scientific-surveys/|archivedate=2017-09-11|df=}}</ref> However, use of [[Amazon Mechanical Turk|Mechanical Turk]] tends to quickly produce more diverse participant backgrounds, as well as comparably accurate data when compared to traditional collection methods.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Michael Buhrmester, Tracy Kwang, and Samuel D. Gosling|first=|date=2011|title=Amazon’s Mechanical Turk: A New Source of Inexpensive, Yet High-Quality, Data?|url=https://www.pomona.edu/sites/default/files/buhrmester_-crowdsourcing-amazon-mturk.pdf|journal=Perspectives on Psychological Science|volume=6|pages=3–5|via=SAGE|doi=10.1177/1745691610393980|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160729100125/https://www.pomona.edu/sites/default/files/buhrmester_-crowdsourcing-amazon-mturk.pdf|archivedate=2016-07-29|df=}}</ref>
The internet has also enabled citizen scientists to gather data to be analyzed by professional researchers. Citizen science networks are often involved in the observation of cyclic events of nature ([[phenology]]), such as effects of global warming on plant and animal life in different geographic areas,<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/2008/0410/p14s01-sten.html "Citizen scientists" watch for signs of climate change] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411230403/http://www.csmonitor.com/2008/0410/p14s01-sten.html |date=2008-04-11 }}, ''The Christian Science Monitor'', April 10, 2008.</ref> and in monitoring programs for natural-resource management.<ref>Ballard, H., Pilz, D., Jones, E.T., and Getz, C. (2005). Training Curriculum for Scientists and Managers: Broadening Participation in Biological Monitoring. Corvallis, OR: Institute for Culture and Ecology.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cooper | first1 = C. B. | last2 = Dickinson | first2 = J. | last3 = Phillips | first3 = T. | last4 = Bonney | first4 = R. | year = 2007 | title = Citizen Science as a Tool for Conservation in Residential Ecosystems | url = | journal = Ecology and Society | volume = 12 | issue = 2 | doi=10.5751/es-02197-120211}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1 = Firehock |first1 = K. |last2 = West |first2 = J. |title = A Brief History of Volunteer Biological Water Monitoring Using Macroinvertebrates |journal = Journal of the North American Benthological Society |volume = 14 |issue = 1 |pages = 197–202 |doi = 10.2307/1467734 |year = 1995 |pmid = |pmc =}}</ref> On [[BugGuide]].Net, an online community of naturalists who share observations of [[arthropod]], amateurs and professional researchers contribute to the analysis. By October 2014, BugGuide has over 808,718 images submitted by more than 27,846 contributors.<ref name=BG_Stats>{{cite web|title=BugGuide System Statistics |url=http://bugguide.net/node/view/11181 |publisher=BugGuide.net |date=6 October 2014 |accessdate=6 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130425102840/http://bugguide.net/node/view/11181 |archivedate=25 April 2013 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:Bubbles Within Bubbles.jpg|thumb|An NASA/JPL image from the Zooniverse's [[The Milky Way Project]] showing a hierarchical bubble structure]]
The [[Zooniverse (citizen science project)|Zooniverse]] is home to the internet's largest, most popular and most successful citizen science projects.<ref name=ESERO>{{cite web|title=New Zooniverse projects – Bat Detective and Click to Cure|url=http://www.esero.org.uk/news/new-zooniverse-projects-bat-detective-and-click-to-cure|publisher=European Space Education Resource Office|date=30 October 2012|accessdate=8 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141014070524/http://www.esero.org.uk/news/new-zooniverse-projects-bat-detective-and-click-to-cure|archivedate=14 October 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tinati|first1=Ramine|last2=van Kleek|first2=Max|last3=Simperl|first3=Elena|last4=Luczak-Roesch|first4=Markus|last5=Simpson|first5=Robert|last6=Shadbolt|first6=Nigel|title=Designing for Citizen Data Analysis: A Cross-Sectional Case Study of a Multi-Domain Citizen Science Platform|journal=In Proceedings of the 33rd Annual ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI '15).|pages=4069–4078|doi=10.1145/2702123.2702420|year=2015}}</ref> The Zooniverse and the suite of projects it contains is produced, maintained and developed by the Citizen Science Alliance (CSA).<ref name=CSA>{{cite web|title=Citizen Science Alliance website|url=http://www.citizensciencealliance.org|accessdate=28 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812000639/http://www.citizensciencealliance.org/|archivedate=12 August 2014|df=}}</ref> The member institutions of the CSA work with many academic and other partners around the world to produce projects that use the efforts and ability of volunteers to help scientists and researchers deal with the flood of data that confronts them. On June 29, 2015, the Zooniverse released a new software version with a project-building tool allowing any registered user to create a project.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lintott|first1=Chris|title=A Whole New Zooniverse|url=https://blog.zooniverse.org/2015/06/29/a-whole-new-zooniverse/|website=Zooniverse Blog|accessdate=15 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617133346/https://blog.zooniverse.org/2015/06/29/a-whole-new-zooniverse/|archivedate=17 June 2016|df=}}</ref> Project owners may optionally complete an approval process to have their projects listed on the Zooniverse site and promoted to the Zooniverse community.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zooniverse Project Builder Policies, or So You Want To Launch a Project?|url=https://www.zooniverse.org/lab-policies|website=Zooniverse|accessdate=15 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617144633/https://www.zooniverse.org/lab-policies|archivedate=17 June 2016|df=}}</ref> A NASA/JPL picture to the right gives an example from one of Zooniverse's projects [[The Milky Way Project]].
The website [[CosmoQuest]] has as its goal "To create a community of people bent on together advancing our understanding of the universe; a community of people who are participating in doing science, who can explain why what they do matters, and what questions they are helping to answer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cosmoquest.org/x/about/|title=About Us|work=cosmoquest.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160803003859/http://cosmoquest.org/x/about/|archivedate=2016-08-03|df=}}</ref>
CrowdCrafting enables its participants to create and run projects where volunteers help with image classification, transcription, geocoding and more.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://crowdcrafting.org/about|title=crowdcrafting|author=Scifabric|work=Crowdcrafting|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171102215736/https://crowdcrafting.org/about|archivedate=2017-11-02|df=}}</ref> The platform is powered by PyBossa software, a free and open-source framework for crowdsourcing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pybossa.com/|title=PyBossa|author=Shuttleworth Foundation|work=pybossa.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105154726/http://pybossa.com/|archivedate=2018-01-05|df=}}</ref>
Project Soothe is a citizen science research project based at the University of Edinburgh. The aim of this research is to create a bank of soothing images, submitted by members of the public, which can be used to help others through psychotherapy and research in the future. Since 2015, Project Soothe has received over 600 soothing photographs from people in 23 countries. Anyone aged 12 years or over are eligible to participate in this research in two ways: (1) By submitting soothing photos that they have taken with a description of why the images make them feel soothed (2) By rating the photos that have been submitted by people worldwide for their soothability. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.projectsoothe.com/participate/4593532002|author=Project Soothe|title=Participate in Project Soothe|work=www.projectsoothe.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180119235525/http://www.projectsoothe.com/participate/4593532002|archivedate=2018-01-19|df=}}</ref>
===Smartphone bandwidth===
The bandwidth and ubiquity afforded by smartphone technology has vastly expanded the opportunities for citizen science. Examples include [[iNaturalist]], the San Francisco project, the WildLab, Project Noah,<ref name=PkSc>{{cite web|title=San Francisco Parks Alliance ParkScan|url=http://www.sfparksalliance.org/our-work/policy/research/parkscan|publisher=San Francisco Parks Alliance|date=2014|accessdate=5 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805103901/http://www.sfparksalliance.org/our-work/policy/research/parkscan|archivedate=5 August 2016|df=}}</ref><ref name=WiLa>{{cite web|title=The Wildlab|url=http://www.thewildlab.org|publisher=The Wildlab|date=2016|accessdate=5 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160824232455/http://www.thewildlab.org/|archivedate=24 August 2016|df=}}</ref><ref name=PrjNoah>{{cite web|url=http://www.projectnoah.org|title=Project Noah|publisher=Networked Organisms|date=2016|accessdate=5 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160812112645/http://www.projectnoah.org/|archivedate=12 August 2016|df=}}</ref> and Aurorasurus. Due to their ubiquity, for example, [[Twitter]], [[Facebook]], and [[smartphone]]s have been useful for citizen scientists, having enabled them to discover and propagate a new type of aurora dubbed "STEVE" in 2016.<ref name="Twitter and Citizen science">{{cite web |url=http://www.gi.alaska.edu/Alaska-Science-Forum/citizen-science-meets-aurora |title=Citizen science meets the aurora |last=Rozell |first=Ned |date=2015-04-02 |website=University of Alaska Fairbanks Geophysical Institute |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731234543/http://www.gi.alaska.edu/Alaska-Science-Forum/citizen-science-meets-aurora |archivedate=2017-07-31 |df= }}</ref>
There are also [[smartphone]] [[Mobile app|apps]] for monitoring birds, marine wildlife and other organisms, and the "Loss of the Night".<ref name=C.Clarke_YouTube>{{cite web|title=Citizen science: Chandra Clarke at TEDxChathamKent|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U7XOcB6_TWw|publisher=YouTube|date=14 March 2014|accessdate=15 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140801223346/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U7XOcB6_TWw|archivedate=1 August 2014|df=}}</ref><ref name=lotn_discovery>{{cite news|last=O'Hanlon|first=Larry|title=Turn Yourself into a Skyglow Meter|url=http://news.discovery.com/space/astronomy/turn-yourself-into-a-skyglow-meter-130501.htm|accessdate=8 May 2013|newspaper=Discovery News|date=1 May 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130503003739/http://news.discovery.com/space/astronomy/turn-yourself-into-a-skyglow-meter-130501.htm|archivedate=3 May 2013|df=}}</ref>
An [[Android (operating system)|Android]] app Sapelli is a mobile data-collection and -sharing platform designed with a particular focus on non-literate and illiterate users with little or no prior ICT experience.<ref name=Sap>{{cite web|title=Sapelli|url=https://www.ucl.ac.uk/excites/software/sapelli|publisher=University College London|date=2016|accessdate=5 August 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817000416/https://www.ucl.ac.uk/excites/software/sapelli|archivedate=17 August 2016|df=}}</ref> A smartphone focussed platform for Citizen Science applications is SPOTTERON, which creates synergy effects for projects by sharing a common feature set.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=2018-11-06|title=Austrian Citizen Science Conference 2018|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.3389/978-2-88945-587-4|journal=Austrian Citizen Science Conference 2018|publisher=Frontiers Media SA|volume=|pages=66-69|doi=10.3389/978-2-88945-587-4|isbn=9782889455874|via=}}</ref>
"The Crowd and the Cloud" is a four-part series broadcast during April 2017, which examines citizen science.<ref name=Crowd&Cloud>{{cite web| title=The Crowd and the Cloud| url=http://crowdandcloud.org| website=The Crowd and the Cloud| accessdate=24 April 2017| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170425030405/http://crowdandcloud.org/| archivedate=25 April 2017| df=}}</ref> It shows how smartphones, computers and mobile technology enable regular citizens to become part of a 21st-century way of doing science.<ref name=Crowd&Cloud/> The programs also demonstrate how CSs help professional scientists to advance knowledge, which helps speed up new discoveries and innovations. The Crowd & The Cloud is based upon work supported by the [[National Science Foundation]].<ref name=Crowd&Cloud/>
===Seismology===
Since 1975, in order to improve earthquake detection and collect useful information, the [[European-Mediterranean Seismological Centre]] monitors the visits of earthquake eyewitnesses to its website and relies on Facebook and Twitter.<ref name=EMSC>{{cite web| title=EMSC History| url=https://www.emsc-csem.org/about| publisher=The European-Mediterranean Seismological Centre| access-date=16 January 2018| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908143401/https://www.emsc-csem.org/about/| archivedate=8 September 2017| df=}}</ref>
===Hydrology===
Citizen science has been used to provide valuable data in [[hydrology]] (catchment science), notably flood risk, [[water quality]] and [[water resource management]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Starkey|first1=Eleanor|last2=Parkin|first2=Geoff|last3=Birkinshaw|first3=Steve|last4=Large|first4=Andy|last5=Quinn|first5=Paul|last6=Gibson|first6=Ceri|title=Demonstrating the value of community-based (‘citizen science’) observations for catchment modelling and characterisation|journal=Journal of Hydrology|date=2017|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022169417301646|doi=10.1016/j.jhydrol.2017.03.019|bibcode=2017JHyd..548..801S}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Community Involvement in UK Catchment Management|url=http://www.fwr.org/Catchment/frr0021.pdf|publisher=Foundation for Water Research|accessdate=27 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428053522/http://www.fwr.org/Catchment/frr0021.pdf|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}}</ref> A growth in internet use and smartphone ownership has allowed users to collect and share real-time flood-risk information using, for example, social media and web-based forms. Although traditional data collection methods are well-established, citizen science is being used to fill the data gaps on a local level, and is therefore meaningful to individual communities. It has been demonstrated that citizen science is particularly advantageous during a [[flash flood]] because the public are more likely to witness these rarer hydrological events than scientists.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Newcastle University|title=Communities can fill the gaps on flooding|url=http://www.ncl.ac.uk/press/news/2017/04/communityfloodmonitoring/|accessdate=27 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428051503/http://www.ncl.ac.uk/press/news/2017/04/communityfloodmonitoring/|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}}</ref>
==Africa and South America==
There are many CS projects in [[Africa]] and [[South America]]. Some examples in Africa are:
*In [[South Africa]] (SA), CS projects include: the Stream Assessment Scoring System (miniSASS) which "encourages enhanced catchment management for water security in a climate stressed society."<ref name=SASS>{{cite web|title=Healthy Rivers – Healthy people: Citizen Science for sustainable water management in a climate stressed society|url=http://www.wessa.org.za/what-we-do/water-programme/healthy-rivers-healthy-people.htm|publisher=The Wildlife and Environment Society of South Africa|date=2014|accessdate=20 July 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817021400/http://www.wessa.org.za/what-we-do/water-programme/healthy-rivers-healthy-people.htm|archivedate=17 August 2016|df=}}</ref> [[File:Snapshot serengeti.jpg|thumb|right|Snapshot Serengeti classifies animals at the [[Serengeti National Park]] in [[Tanzania]]]] *Also in SA, "Members of the public, or 'citizen scientists' are helping researchers from the University of Pretoria to identify Phytophthora species present in the fynbos."<ref name=CS_Fynbos>{{cite web|title=Citizen engagement in research to protect fynbos – and forests|author=Joey Hulbert|url=http://saforestryonline.co.za/articles/citizen-engagement-research-protect-fynbos-forests|publisher=SA Forestry Online|date=10 February 2016|accessdate=20 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160802102813/http://saforestryonline.co.za/articles/citizen-engagement-research-protect-fynbos-forests/|archivedate=2 August 2016|df=}}</ref> *In June 2016, citizen science experts from across East Africa gathered in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]] for a symposium organised by the Tropical Biology Association (TBA) in partnership with the Centre for Ecology & Hydrology (CEH). The aim was "to harness the growing interest and expertise in East Africa to stimulate new ideas and collaborations in citizen science." Rosie Trevelyan of the TBA said: "We need to enhance our knowledge about the status of Africa's species and the threats facing them. And scientists can't do it all on their own. At the same time, citizen science is an extremely effective way of connecting people more closely to nature and enrolling more people in conservation action".<ref name=TBA_CEH>{{cite web|title=Citizen science takes a leap forward in East Africa|url=http://www.tropical-biology.org/citizen-science-takes-a-leap-forward-in-east-africa|publisher=Tropical Biology Association|date=June 2016|accessdate=20 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712090949/http://www.tropical-biology.org/citizen-science-takes-a-leap-forward-in-east-africa/|archivedate=12 July 2016|df=}}</ref> *The website Zooniverse hosts several African CS projects, including: Snapshot Serengeti, Wildcam Gorongosa and Jungle Rhythms.<ref name=Zoo_CS>{{cite web|title=Zooniverse CS projects in [[South America]] include: [[File:Ashaninca children in school.jpg|thumb|right|Asháninka children in school]] *In 2015 the [[Asháninka people]] from Apiwtxa, which crosses the border between [[Brazil]] and [[Peru]], began using the Android app Sapelli to monitor their land. The Ashaninka have "faced historical pressures of disease, exploitation and displacement, and today still face the illegal invasion of their lands by loggers and hunters. This monitoring project shows how the Apiwtxa Ashaninka from the Kampa do Rio Amônia Indigenous Territory, Brazil, are beginning to use smartphones and technological tools to monitor these illegal activities more effectively."<ref name=Ash_Api>{{cite web|title=Ashaninka Land Monitoring Initiative|url=http://forestcompass.org/case-studies/ashaninka-land-monitoring-initiative|publisher=Global Canopy Programme|date=April 2016|accessdate=20 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423075020/http://forestcompass.org/case-studies/ashaninka-land-monitoring-initiative|archivedate=23 April 2016|df=}}</ref> *In [[Argentina]], two smartphone [[Android (operating system)|Android]] applications are available for CS. '''i)''' AppEAR has been developed at the Institute of [[Limnology]] and was launched in May 2016.<ref name=AppEAR>{{cite web|title=AppEAR: una aplicación para estudiar ambientes acuáticos con colaboración ciudadana|author=Marcelo Gisande|url=http://www.conicet.gov.ar/appear-una-aplicacion-para-estudiar-ambientes-acuaticos-con-colaboracion-ciudadana|publisher=CONICET|date=7 June 2016|accessdate=1 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160812041610/http://www.conicet.gov.ar/appear-una-aplicacion-para-estudiar-ambientes-acuaticos-con-colaboracion-ciudadana/|archivedate=12 August 2016|df=}}</ref> Joaquín Coachman is a researcher who developed an "application that appeals to the collaboration of users of mobile devices in collecting data that allow the study of aquatic ecosystems" (translation).<ref name=AppEAR/> Coachman stated: "Not much of citizen science in Argentina, just a few more oriented to astronomy specific cases. As ours is the first. And I have volunteers from different parts of the country that are interested in joining together to centralize data. That's great because these types of things require many people participate actively and voluntarily" (translation).<ref name=AppEAR/> '''ii)''' eBird was launched in 2013, and has so far identified 965 species of birds.<ref name=Arg_ebird>{{cite web|title=Ciencia ciudadana: la cultura de la colaboración|author=Federico Kukso|url=http://fkukso.com/post/86028119770/ciencia-ciudadana-la-cultura-de-la-colaboraci%C3%B3n|date=2016|accessdate=1 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160829065141/http://fkukso.com/post/86028119770/ciencia-ciudadana-la-cultura-de-la-colaboraci%C3%B3n|archivedate=29 August 2016|df=}}</ref> eBird in Argentina is "developed and managed by the Cornell Lab of Ornithology at [[Cornell University]], one of the most important ornithological institutions in the world, and locally presented recently with the support of the Ministry of Science, Technology and Productive Innovation of the Nation (MINCyT)" (translation).<ref name=Arg_ebird/> *Projects in [[Brazil]] include: '''i)''' Platform and mobile app 'Missions' has been developed by [[IBM]] in their [[São Paulo]] research lab with Brazil's Ministry for Environment and Innovation (BMEI).<ref name=Mission>{{cite news|title=IBM and SAP open up big data platforms for citizen science|author=Kristine A. Wong|publisher=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/tech-giants-ibm-sap-citizen-science-big-data|date=27 January 2014|accessdate=2 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160826070641/https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/tech-giants-ibm-sap-citizen-science-big-data|archivedate=26 August 2016|df=}}</ref> Sergio Borger, an IBM team lead in São Paulo, devised the crowdsourced approach when BMEI approached the company in 2010. They were looking for a way to create a central repository for the rainforest data.<ref name=Mission/> Users can upload photos of a plant species and its components, enter its characteristics (such as color and size), compare it against a catalog photo and classify it. The classification results are juried by crowdsourced ratings.<ref name=Mission/> '''ii)''' Exoss Citizen Science is a member of Astronomers Without Borders and seeks to explore the southern sky for new meteors and radiants.<ref name=Exoss>{{cite web|title=Exoss Citizen Science|url=http://astronomerswithoutborders.org/my-awb/our-current-affiliates/network.html?id=510|publisher=Astronomy Without Borders|date=July 2015|accessdate=2 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818054051/http://astronomerswithoutborders.org/my-awb/our-current-affiliates/network.html?id=510|archivedate=18 August 2016|df=}}</ref> Users can report meteor fireballs through uploading pictures on to a webpage or by linking to [[YouTube]].<ref name=Exoss/> [[File:Jaguar in Pantanal Brazil 2.jpg|thumb|right|A jaguar in [[Pantanal]]; an example of Brazilian [[biodiversity]].]] '''iii)''' The Information System on Brazilian Biodiversity (SiBBr) was launched in 2014 "aiming to encourage and facilitate the publication, integration, access and use of information about the biodiversity of the country."<ref name=SiBBr>{{cite web|title=SiBBr completes one year with six million records on biodiversity|url=https://www.rnp.br/en/noticias/sibbr-completa-ano-seis-milhoes-registros|publisher=RNP|date=26 November 2015|accessdate=3 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160920002851/https://www.rnp.br/en/noticias/sibbr-completa-ano-seis-milhoes-registros|archivedate=20 September 2016|df=}}</ref> Their initial goal "was to gather 2.5 million occurrence records of species from biological collections in Brazil and abroad up to the end of 2016. It is now expected that SiBBr reach 9 million of records in 2016." Andrea Portela said: "In 2016, we will begin with the citizen science. They are tools that enable anyone, without any technical knowledge, to participate. With this we will achieve greater engagement with society. People will be able to have more interaction with the platform, contribute and comment on what Brazil has.<ref name=SiBBr/> '''iv)''' The Brazilian Marine Megafauna Project (Iniciativa Pro Mar) is working with the European CSA towards its main goal, which is the "sensibilization of society for marine life issues" and concerns about pollution and the over-exploitation of natural resources.<ref name=IPM>{{cite web|title=Brasil Megafauna Marinha|url=http://ecsa.citizen-science.net/profile-supporter_profile/490|publisher=ECSA|accessdate=3 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818122208/http://ecsa.citizen-science.net/profile-supporter_profile/490|archivedate=18 August 2016|df=}}</ref> Having started as a project monitoring [[manta ray]], it now extends to [[whale shark]] and educating schools and divers within the Santos area.<ref name=IPM/> Its social media activities include a live streaming of a CS course to help divers identify marine megafauna.<ref name=IPM/> '''v)''' A smartphone app called Plantix has been developed by the Leibniz Centre for Agricultural Landscape Research (ZALF) which helps Brazilian farmers discover crop diseases quicker and helps fight them more efficiently.<ref name=Zalf>{{cite web|title=Crop protection via smart phone: ZALF and PEAT start new Citizen Science project|url=http://www.zalf.de/en/aktuelles/meldungen_alle/Pages/LSA/Plantix.aspx|publisher=Leibniz-Zentrum für Agrarlandschaftsforschung|accessdate=3 August 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818020517/http://www.zalf.de/en/aktuelles/meldungen_alle/Pages/LSA/Plantix.aspx|archivedate=18 August 2016|df=}}</ref> Brazil is a very large agricultural exporter, but between 10-30% of crops fail because of disease.<ref name=Zalf/> "The database currently includes 175 frequently occurring crop diseases and pests as well as 40,000 photos. The identification [[algorithm]] of the app improves with every image which records a success rate of over 90 per cent as of approximately 500 photos per crop disease."<ref name=Zalf/> '''vi)''' In an [[Atlantic Ocean]] forest region in Brazil, an effort to map the genetic riches of soil is under way.<ref name=DFD>{{cite web|title=Citizen scientists sift soil for new antibiotics|author=Penny Sarchet|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn26825-citizen-scientists-sift-soil-for-new-antibiotics|publisher=RBI|date=20 January 2015|accessdate=3 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160413024228/https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn26825-citizen-scientists-sift-soil-for-new-antibiotics/|archivedate=13 April 2016|df=}}</ref> The Drugs From Dirt initiative, based at the [[Rockefeller University]], seeks to turn up [[bacteria]] that yield new types of antibiotics- the Brazilian region being particularly rich in potentially useful bacterial genes.<ref name=DFD/> Approximately a quarter of the 185 soil samples have been taken by Citizen Scientists without which the project could not run.<ref name=DFD/> *In [[Chile]] CS projects include (some websites in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]): '''i)''' Testing new cancer therapies with scientists from the Science Foundation for Life.<ref name=Ch_CS>{{cite web|title=Chilecientifico Ciencia Ciudadana|publisher=Chilecientífico|url=http://chilecientifico.cl/participar.html|accessdate=29 July 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160628075551/http://chilecientifico.cl/participar.html|archivedate=28 June 2016|df=}}</ref> '''ii)''' Monitoring the population of the Chilean [[bumblebee]].<ref name=BB_FB>{{cite web|title=Saving Chile's bumblebee from extinction|publisher=Bee Safe|url=http://www.bee-safe.eu/save-chiles-bumblebee-from-extinction|date=1 February 2016|accessdate=29 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916060258/http://www.bee-safe.eu/save-chiles-bumblebee-from-extinction/|archivedate=16 September 2016|df=}}</ref> '''iii)''' Monitoring the invasive [[Coccinellidae|ladybird]] Chinita arlequín.<ref name=Ch_Ar>{{cite web|title=Chinita arlequin: Harmonia axryidis en Chile|author1=A.A. Grez|author2=T. Zaviezo|url=http://www.chinita-arlequin.uchile.cl|publisher=Chinita Arlequín en Chile|date=2015|accessdate=29 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160802030754/http://www.chinita-arlequin.uchile.cl/|archivedate=2 August 2016|df=}}</ref> '''iv)''' Collecting rain water data.<ref name=Ch_RW>{{cite web|title=Pluviómetros Ciudadanos|url=http://milluvia.dga.cl/index.php|publisher=Dirección General de Aguas: Ministerio de Obras Públicas|accessdate=29 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820124029/http://milluvia.dga.cl/index.php|archivedate=20 August 2016|df=}}</ref> '''(v)''' Monitoring various pollinating [[fly]] populations.<ref name=MFC>{{cite web|title=Moscas Floricholas de Chile|url=https://www.facebook.com/groups/774986852548819|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=29 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170122141323/https://www.facebook.com/groups/774986852548819|archivedate=22 January 2017|df=}}</ref> '''(vi)''' Providing information and field data on the abundance and distribution of various species of [[Sebastidae|rockfish]].<ref name=Ch_RFish>{{cite web|title=Lanzamiento Programa Primera Red de Buzos Deportivos para la Conservación de Peces de Roca|url=http://www.costahumboldt.org/2015/01/27/lanzamiento-programa-primera-red-de-buzos-deportivos-para-la-conservacion-de-peces-de-roca|publisher=Costa Humboldt|date=27 January 2015|accessdate=29 July 2016}}</ref> [[File:Árboles en Bogotá - Humedal de Córdoba Vegetación.JPG|thumb|right|[[Córdoba (wetland)|Córdoba wetland]]]] *Projects in [[Colombia]] include (some websites in Spanish): '''i)''' The Communications Project of the Humboldt Institute along with the Organization for Education and Environmental Protection initiated projects in the [[Bogotá]] [[wetlands]] of [[Córdoba (wetland)|Cordoba]] and [[El Burro]], which have a lot of [[biodiversity]].<ref name=HI_Wet>{{cite web| title=Concluyó proyecto piloto de ciencia ciudadana en humedales de Bogotá| url=http://www.humboldt.org.co/es/noticias/notas/item/243-concluyo-proyecto-piloto-de-ciencia-ciudadana-en-humedales-de-bogota| publisher=Humboldt Institute| date=2014| accessdate=30 July 2016| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816145953/http://www.humboldt.org.co/es/noticias/notas/item/243-concluyo-proyecto-piloto-de-ciencia-ciudadana-en-humedales-de-bogota| archivedate=16 August 2016| df=}}</ref><ref name=OpEPA>{{cite web| title=Organización para la Educación y Protección Ambiental| url=http://www.opepa.org| publisher=OpEPA| date=2016| accessdate=30 July 2016| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160810092951/http://opepa.org/| archivedate=10 August 2016| df=}}</ref> '''ii)''' In the Model Forest of Risaralda, the Colombia {{lang|es|'proyecto de Ciencia Abierta y Colaborativa'}} promotes citizen participation in research related to the local environment is adapting to climate change. The first meeting took place in the Flora and Fauna Sanctuary Otún Quimbaya.<ref name=PCA>{{cite web| title=Ciencia ciudadana en el Bosque Modelo Risaralda, Colombia| author=Comunicación RIABM editor| url=http://www.bosquesmodelo.net/ciencia-ciudadana-en-el-bosque-modelo-risaralda-colombia| publisher=Red Iberoamericana de Bosques Modelo| date=4 August 2015| accessdate=30 July 2016| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161017063902/http://www.bosquesmodelo.net/ciencia-ciudadana-en-el-bosque-modelo-risaralda-colombia/| archivedate=17 October 2016| df=}}</ref> '''iii''') The Citizen Network Environmental Monitoring (CLUSTER), based in the city of [[Bucaramanga]], seeks to engage younger students in data science, who are trained in building weather stations with open repositories based on free software and open hardware data.<ref name=Cluster>{{cite web| title=Red Ambiental Ciudadana de Monitoreo (RACIMO)| url=http://halley.uis.edu.co/tierra/?page_id=143| publisher=Racimo| accessdate=30 July 2016| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160809220831/http://halley.uis.edu.co/tierra/?page_id=143| archivedate=9 August 2016| df=}}</ref> '''iv)''' The Symposium on Biodiversity has adapted the CS tool iNaturalist for use in Colombia.<ref name=SIB>{{cite web| title=SIB Report No.2| url=http://www.sibcolombia.net/web/sib/2013-2| publisher=Sistema de información sobre Biodiversidad de Colombia| date=2013| accessdate=30 July 2016| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818085623/http://www.sibcolombia.net/web/sib/2013-2| archivedate=18 August 2016| df=}}</ref> '''v)''' The [[Sinchi Amazonic Institute of Scientific Research]] seeks to encourage the development and diffusion of knowledge, values and technologies on the management of natural resources for ethnic groups in the Amazon. This research should further the use of participatory action research schemes and promoting participation communities.<ref name=Si_Inst>{{cite web| title=Funciones del Instituto| url=http://www.sinchi.org.co/index.php/funciones| publisher=The Sinchi Institute| accessdate=30 July 2016| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820091926/http://www.sinchi.org.co/index.php/funciones| archivedate=20 August 2016| df=}}</ref> *Since 2010, the Pacific Biodiversity Institute (PBI) seeks "volunteers to help identify, describe and protect wildland complexes and roadless areas in South America". The PBI "are engaged in an ambitious project with our Latin American conservation partners to map all the wildlands in South America, to evaluate their contribution to global biodiversity and to share and disseminate this information."<ref name=PBI>{{cite web|title=Citizen Science Volunteers needed for mapping South American Wetlands|url=http://www.pacificbio.org/helpout/volunteer-south-america.html|publisher=Pacific Biodiversity Institute|accessdate=20 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160827190519/http://www.pacificbio.org/helpout/volunteer-south-america.html|archivedate=27 August 2016|df=}}</ref>

The first Conference on Public Participation in Scientific Research was held in Portland, Oregon in August 2012.<ref name="Rosner2013">{{cite journal|last1=Rosner|first1=Hillary|title=Data on Wings|journal=Scientific American|volume=308|issue=2|year=2013|pages=68–73|issn=0036-8733|doi=10.1038/scientificamerican0213-68|bibcode = 2013SciAm.308b..68R}}</ref> Citizen science is now often a theme at large conferences, such as the annual meeting of the [[American Geophysical Union]].<ref name=AGU_Meeting>{{cite web|title=ED51A. In January 2015, the [[ETH Zürich]] and [[University of Zürich]] hosted an international meeting on the "Challenges and Opportunities in Citizen Science".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imsb.ethz.ch/news-and-events/events/citizenscienceworkshop/Program.html|title=Program|work=ethz.ch|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161103001056/http://www.imsb.ethz.ch/news-and-events/events/citizenscienceworkshop/Program.html|archivedate=2016-11-03|df=}}</ref>
The first citizen science conference hosted by the Citizen Science Association was in San Jose, California, in February 2015 in partnership with the AAAS conference.<ref name=CSA_Feb2015>{{cite web|title=Conference February 11th-12th, San Jose, California, USA|url=http://citizenscienceassociation.org/conference|publisher=Citizen Science Association|accessdate=15 September 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140915231307/http://citizenscienceassociation.org/conference/|archivedate=15 September 2014|df=}}</ref> The Citizen Science Association conference, CitSci 2017, was held in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|Saint Paul]], [[Minnesota]], United States, between May 17 and 20, 2017. page.title: Committee on the Public Understanding of Science

revision.text:
The '''Committee on the Public Understanding of Science''' or '''Copus''' was founded in 1985 by the [[British Association for the Advancement of Science]] (BAAS), the [[Royal Institution]] and the [[Royal Society]]. Its aim was to interpret scientific advances and make them more accessible to non-scientists.
It played a part in developing the [[Public awareness of science|public understanding of science]] it establishing standards for communicating science and technology
The Copus Grant Schemes was set up in 1987 and the last round of grants was for 2003/4. The scheme was funded by the [[Office of Science and Technology]] and the [[Royal Society]]. 25 grants worth a total of over £750,000 were awarded in 2003/2004.
In 2000 The new Copus Council was formed to be a more inclusive partnership for science communication in the UK.<ref>https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld199900/ldselect/ldsctech/38/3805.htm</ref> In 2002 following a report commissioned by the [[Office of Science and Technology]] the Copus Council was discontinued.
